DataElement.preferredName: Cancer Identification Histology and Behavior ICD-O-2 Code
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The codes that describe a group of subfields describing the type and behavior of the tumor being reported using ICD-O-2 codes.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Cancer Identification Histology and Behavior ICD-O-2
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A group of subfields describing the type and behavior of the tumor being reported using ICD-O-2 codes.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues.  Malignant neoplasms usually metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision.  The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas. -- 2004:Identified; having the identity known or established.

Concepts.definition: A neoplasm composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.
The procedure of having an identity established.

Property.preferredName: Histology Behavior International Classification of Disease for Oncology
Property.preferredDefinition: The study of the structure of the cells and their arrangement to constitute tissues and, finally, the association among these to form organs.  In pathology, the microscopic process of identifying normal and abnormal morphologic characteristics in tissues, by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains.:human or animal activity studied in terms of motivation, direction, result, emotion, perception, or etiology.:The International Classification of Disease for Oncology has been used for nearly 25 years as a tool for coding diagnoses of neoplasms in tumor and cancer registrars and in pathology laboratories. ICD-O is a dual classification with coding systems for both topography and morphology. The topography code describes the site of origin of the neoplasm. The morphology code describes the characteristics of the tumor itself, including its cell type and biologic activity. (from Amazon.com)

Concepts.definition: The study of the structure of the cells and their arrangement to constitute tissues and, finally, the association among these to form organs.  In pathology, the microscopic process of identifying normal and abnormal morphologic characteristics in tissues, by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains.
The actions or reactions of an object or organism, usually in relation to the environment or surrounding world of stimuli.

Concepts.longName: International Classification of Diseases for Oncology
Concepts.definition: The International Classification of Diseases for Oncology has been used for nearly 25 years as a tool for coding diagnoses of neoplasms in tumor and cancer registrars and in pathology laboratories. ICD-O is a dual classification with coding systems for both topography and morphology. The topography code describes the site of origin of the neoplasm. The morphology code describes the characteristics of the tumor itself, including its cell type and biologic activity. (from Amazon.com)

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: The distinguishing qualities or prominent aspect of a person, object, action, process, or substance.

DataElementConcept.origin: NAACCR:North American Association of Central Cancer Registries

ValueDomain.preferredName: Histology and Behavior International Classification of Diseases Oncology 2 (ICD-O-2) Code
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: The study of the structure of the cells and their arrangement to constitute tissues and, finally, the association among these to form organs. In pathology, the microscopic process of identifying normal and abnormal morphologic characteristics in tissues, by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains._The actions or reactions of an object or organism, usually in relation to the environment or surrounding world of stimuli._A system of categories to which morbid entries are assigned according to established criteria. Included is the entire range of conditions in a manageable number of categories, grouped to facilitate mortality reporting. It is produced by the World Health Organization (from ICD-10, p1). The Clinical Modifications, produced by the United States Dept. of Health and Human Services, are larger extensions used for morbidity and general epidemiological purposes, primarily in the U.S. (MSH2005_2004_10_12)_The study of tumors encompassing the physical, chemical, and biologic properties._A natural number greater than 1 and less than 3 and the quantity that it denotes: the sum of one and one._A system of numbered categories for representation of data. [Explanatory Comment: See ICD-O-2 Morphology Section and Behavior Section for codes.]

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Conceptual entities required by NCI operations and systems. Includes administrative, financial, organizational and quasi-scientific concepts required for NCI operations and systems.

RepresentationTerm.preferredName: Histology Behavior International Classification of Diseases Oncology Two Code
RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: The study of the structure of the cells and their arrangement to constitute tissues and, finally, the association among these to form organs.  In pathology, the microscopic process of identifying normal and abnormal morphologic characteristics in tissues, by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains._The actions or reactions of an object or organism, usually in relation to the environment or surrounding world of stimuli._A system of categories to which morbid entries are assigned according to established criteria. Included is the entire range of conditions in a manageable number of categories, grouped to facilitate mortality reporting. It is produced by the World Health Organization. The Clinical Modifications, produced by the United States Dept. of Health and Human Services, are larger extensions used for morbidity and general epidemiological purposes, primarily in the U.S._The study of tumors encompassing the physical, chemical, and biologic properties._A natural number greater than 1 and less than 3 and the quantity that it denotes: the sum of one and one._A symbol or combination of symbols which is assigned to the members of a collection.

Concepts.definition: The study of the structure of the cells and their arrangement to constitute tissues and, finally, the association among these to form organs.  In pathology, the microscopic process of identifying normal and abnormal morphologic characteristics in tissues, by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains.
The actions or reactions of an object or organism, usually in relation to the environment or surrounding world of stimuli.

A system of categories to which morbid entries are assigned according to established criteria. Included is the entire range of conditions in a manageable number of categories, grouped to facilitate mortality reporting. It is produced by the World Health Organization. The Clinical Modifications, produced by the United States Dept. of Health and Human Services, are larger extensions used for morbidity and general epidemiological purposes, primarily in the U.S.
The study of tumors encompassing the physical, chemical, and biologic properties.
A natural number greater than 1 and less than 3 and the quantity that it denotes: the sum of one and one.
A symbol or combination of symbols which is assigned to the members of a collection.
